node.title: TemperatureDependentHardeningStressUpdate not handling temperatures out of defined temperature-hardening function range correctly.

node.bodyText: Will update with input file once I make one stripped back to the minimum required to show this issue.

Hello
How would you rather is handles them? Erroring is not always the best option, these values could be visited only temporarily during the nonlinear solve.
Extrapolations eventually dont make sense either.
It's up to modeler to make sure their result is within bounds.
What we should do is document this behavior though. Where is the documentation for that object?
Guillaume

Hi, sorry I've tried recreating this issue in a simpler input file and it seems to be working, so it might have been a different issue previously. I think the current behaviour is the right thing to do, but yes it isn't actually listed in the documentation how this object handles temperatures out of the range for which hardening functions are assigned, which would be a worthwhile addition to the documentation.

node.title: FluxBC -> in the framework source code, not documented?
node.bodyText:
I was browsing for a BC that I could use to set a flux at a boundary, agnostic of the exact physics inside the domain, when I came across FluxBC lying in the source code but isn't documented in https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/syntax/index.html
Is this BC working and advisable for use? Thanks!

Hello
I think you should use a NeumannBC
I ll check this fluxBC but it s probably abusing its name
Guillaume
There is no FluxBC with that name. But there are a couple of specific flux BCs, specific to the physics they are targetted at.

https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/master/framework/src/bcs/FluxBC.C
This is what I found, but it isn't documented.
yeah use a neumannBC, this isnt for users
for more info this is a base class. It s meant to be inherited from to make a specialized flux BC

node.title: For Automatic Periodic Boundary Detection
node.bodyText:
Bug Description
For Automatic Periodic Boundary Detection, can it use the AuxVariables? It is only for the Variables System.
This isn't a bug. You should post in the discussions page.

There are no periodic BCs for AuxVariables because we typically dont set boundary conditions to auxvariables. They are not solved for using a nonlinear solver, they are computed after the fact based on other fields/quantities in a straightforward process using AuxKernels

node.title: Offline libmesh build dies at netcdf
node.bodyText:
make[2]: Leaving directory '/home/mwmoorcroft/moose/libmesh/build/contrib/gzstream'
Making all in netcdf/v4
make[2]: Entering directory '/home/mwmoorcroft/moose/libmesh/build/contrib/netcdf/v4'
make[2]: *** No rule to make target 'all'.  Stop.
make[2]: Leaving directory '/home/mwmoorcroft/moose/libmesh/build/contrib/netcdf/v4'
make[1]: *** [Makefile:1034: all-recursive] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory '/home/mwmoorcroft/moose/libmesh/build/contrib'
make: *** [Makefile:32937: all-recursive] Error 1

Oops, I didn't have the cmake or boost modules loaded. Could be the reason.
Nope, made sure cmake and boost were loaded, but it still dies at the same place.
can you run the diagonistics script in moose/scripts and attach the log please
Once it finishes my latest compile attempt I'll do that. I tried loading the OpenHPC netcdf module.
diag.txt
is this related to this: #21241 (reply in thread)?

Yes, it seemed like I had moved past the original issues. This seems now like a new issue. I notice that netcdf has a lot of curl libs and IP addresses etc in the built config. But this being an offline build with no internet access I'm not sure if it should even be building netcdf? I'm not exactly sure why the build dies there.

netcdf is useful to read files, especially hdf5 exodus files.
Is this solved?

node.title: Using binary = false checkpoint files.
node.bodyText: Hi, I'm working through a seg fault issue when trying to load from checkpoint files, and am attempting to use the binary = false setting in the checkpoint block of my output. This is working sucessfully, and is leading to .cpa and .xda files instead of the normal .cpr and .xdr files. Setting file = xxxx.cpa in mesh is working and the restart is loading the mesh in, however I can't find info on how to tell the problem to search for restart files in the .xda format instead of .xdr, which leads to lots of "unable to find file xxx.xdr" errors when I run. I've tried setting binary = false in problem to mirror the argument given to the checkpoint output, but that doesn't seem to help. Any advice would be appreciated.

Hello
I ll have a look into this
In the mean time you can use a SolutionUO
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobject/SolutionUserObject.html
Guillaume
I'm not sure how well/if that would work when using plasticity, as simply loading displacements in won't correctly recreate the previous state surely?

not sure.
loading from xda should work, the code is there and it's been done by others/
Could you please paste your Problem block here
And also the name of the restart folder and its content
Any news on this?

node.title: Can MOOSE be used to simulate wave equations
node.bodyText:
Hi, everyone
I wonder if MOOSE can be used to simulate wave equations.

In the above picture, the first equation is easy to solve, but the second equation makes me confused as I do not how to solve the term of the second time derivatives of a variable.

Hello
Yes we do support the computation of double derivatives.
in the code you can retrieve them using the Coupleable interface, and in particular the coupledDotDot routine.
In this recent topic someone worked on a wave equation btw
#20925
Guillaume
Thank you for your help

node.title: MeshSideSetGenerator is gone?
node.bodyText:
MOOSE Team,
"MeshSideSetGenerator" seems to be gone from the updated MOOSE.
If so, please let me know an alternative app.
S. Thomas

Hello
We removed it as it was redundant with the LowerDBlockFromSideSetGenerator
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator.html
Guillaume

Thank you Guillaume,
I am studying LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator.  It seems that elements generated by LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator do not have shape functions.
We have been using MeshSideSetGenerator to generate one-dimension-lower finite elements where we assign the diffusion equations with source terms.
We need MeshSideSetGenerator for our model we have been developing for years.
Could you please put MeshSideSetGenerator back into MOOSE?
S. Thomas

Hello
What do you mean they do not have shape functions?
Looking at the code, the lowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator does the same thing but it works for distributed mesh when the other one doesnt.
It should work as is for your case. What errors are you getting?
Guillaume

Guillaume,
I got confused by the documentation.
I replaced MeshSideSetGenerator with LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator and it seems working. :)
It was too simple to believe.
I would like to thank you for your time and help.
Thomas

node.title: A 'AdvectionBC' is not a registered object.
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am trying to develop my own app(name Myself) using MOOSE. I found one bc object called "AdvectionBC" under [(modules/navier_stokes] module (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/AdvectionBC.html#fef0c6df-6c16-4af7-a474-58cc8577c10a). So I copied this one AdvectionBC.h & AdvectionBC.C and changed the register code in AdvectionBC.C file:
registerMooseObject("MyselfAPP", AdvectionBC);
This is the only line I changed to the source code. I put the .h file in the include file and .c file in the src file. I could compile the app but when I am trying to running the input file, it gave me a message that A 'AdvectionBC' is not a registered object..
I am kind of confused since I thought I had registered this object. Is there any other reason that make the registration of object fail?
Thank you so much for any kind of help.

Hello
So first, you dont need to move code over to use these objects. You just need to enable NAVIER_STOKES in the makefile of your application.
Secondly, is your called MyselfApp or myselfApp ? The case is important. you can check the name in src/base/MyselfApp.C.
Guillaume

Yes. I understood I can use the module by enabling it. I just want to build my own application and this is the necessary part.
My application is called MyselfAPP. I saw the "MyselfAPP.C" file in my src file.

then it needs to be registered to MyselfAPP not MyselfApp but that seems weird to me
Just be careful with the case.
If you paste the myselfApp.C file here I can check the app name

I see. I didn't even notice about the case difference. Thank you so much. I changed the name to make sure it was exactly the same as my application name and it worked well now.
Thank you so much for your help.

node.title: Compile libMesh failed using HPC Cluster
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
Recently I wanted to link libmesh directly to moose, and completed the installation of PESTs according to HPC Cluster, the results are as follows,

But when compiling libmesh, ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh, the following error occurs,
-- Done configuring core library features ---
---------------------------------------------
---------------------------------------------
----- Configuring for optional packages -----
---------------------------------------------
checking for built-in XDR support... yes
checking for boostlib >= 1.57.0... configure: We could not detect the boost libraries (version 1.57 or higher). If you have a staged boost library (still not installed) please specify $BOOST_ROOT in your environment and do not give a PATH to --with-boost option.  If you are sure you have boost installed, then check your version number looking in <boost/version.hpp>. See http://randspringer.de/boost for more documentation.
<<< External boost installation *not* found... will try to configure for libmesh's internal boost >>>
checking for boostlib >= 1.57.0... yes
<<< Using libmesh-provided boost in ./contrib >>>
checking for boost::movelib::unique_ptr support... yes
note: Checking /lib and /include for MPI
note: Could not find /lib/libmpi(.a/.so/.dylib)
mpicxx -std=gnu++17 Compiler Supports MPI 
<<< Found PETSc 3.16.5 installation in /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/petsc ... >>>
checking whether we can compile a trivial PETSc program... yes
checking for TAO support via PETSc... yes
configure: error: *** PETSc with Hypre was not found, but --enable-petsc-hypre-required was specified.
Running make -j 1...
make: *** No targets specified and no makefile found.  Stop.

Any suggestions or recommendations to fix the problem would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you
Wei

MOOSE requires libMesh and PETSc. But also that PETSc to be built with HYPRE support (--download-hypre=1 during PETSc configure). You can see the options MOOSE requires or recommends in the moose/scripts/configure_petsc.sh script:
cat moose/scripts/configure_petsc.sh
<trimmed>
  python ./configure --download-hypre=1 \
      --with-shared-libraries=$SHARED \
      "$HDF5_STR" \
      "$HDF5_FORTRAN_STR" \
      "$MAKE_NP_STR" \
      --with-debugging=no \
      --download-fblaslapack=1 \
      --download-metis=1 \
      --download-ptscotch=1 \
      --download-parmetis=1 \
      --download-superlu_dist=1 \
      --download-mumps=1 \
      --download-strumpack=1 \
      --download-scalapack=1 \
      --download-slepc=1 \
      --with-mpi=1 \
      --with-openmp=1 \
      --with-cxx-dialect=C++11 \
      --with-fortran-bindings=0 \
      --with-sowing=0 \
      --with-64-bit-indices \
      "$@"

Oh! Didn't quite catch you used ./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh script.
Can you attach the libmesh_diagnostic.log that was generated? It should be located at moose/scripts/libmesh_diagnostic.log

Yes, I used the update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh script to complete the installation of PETSc.

Can you attach the libmesh_diagnostic.log that was generated? It should be located at moose/scripts/libmesh_diagnostic.log

libmesh_diagnostic.log

The environment does not seem sane to me at the moment. I see references to two different mamba environments (libmesh and moose):
PATH=/home/pengwei/mambaforge3/envs/libmesh/bin
                               ^^^^ (libmesh)
CONDA_BACKUP*=/home/pengwei/mambaforge3/envs/moose
                                        ^^^^ (moose)

Also, having mambaforge3 installed and active, yet:
Python:
	/usr/bin/python
	Python 2.7.18

is really odd. FYI, after we get PETSc/libMesh sorted, you will need to make Python 3 available. As 2.7 is EOL, and will not work with MOOSE.
Can you perform the following and report back:
mamba deactivate
mamba deactivate    # again because you can activate one, and install from that one (which might bring in
                    # stuff from the previous creation)
env
mamba activate libmesh  # I am assuming this is what you wanted as this is the last environment you were in?
mamba list              # Curious what is installed, as it looks like you are using /usr/bin/mpich,
                        # but have created/used our Conda install instructions at one point
Once I see this, we can try to proceed!

I changed the default python to python3 and executed ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh, the output is as follows,
libmesh_diagnostic.log
And the last displayed information is as follows
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Configure complete, now type 'make' and then 'make install'.

---------------------------------------------
--------- Done Configuring libMesh ----------
---------------------------------------------
I'm not sure whether libmesh was installed successfully, so I executed make -j4 in the test path, but the display is as follows,
(libmesh) pengwei@pengwei-virtual-machine: (next)
~/projects/libmesh/moose/test
$ make -j4
make: python-config: Command not found
make: python-config: Command not found
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/build/unity_src/geomsearch_Unity.C...
Creating Unity /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/build/unity_src/splits_Unity.C
Creating Unity /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/build/unity_src/functions_Unity.C
Creating Unity /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/build/unity_src/vectorpostprocessors_Unity.C
Creating Unity /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/build/unity_src/partitioner_Unity.C
Creating Unity /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/build/unity_src/actions_Unity.C
...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/hit/parse.cc...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/hit/lex.cc...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/hit/braceexpr.cc...
Building and linking /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/hit/hit.so...
/home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/hit/hit.cpp:4:10: fatal error: Python.h: No such file or directory
    4 | #include "Python.h"
      |          ^~~~~~~~~~
compilation terminated.
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/ED_SystemInterface.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/create_file.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/stringx.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/exo_block.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/node_set.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/util.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/add_to_log.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/Tolerance.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/STRINGLIB_tokenize.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/map.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/check.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/SL_tokenize.C...
make: *** [/home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/moose.mk:124: /home/pengwei/projects/libmesh/moose/framework/contrib/hit/hit.so] Error 1
make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....

This may also be a problem with the python settings.

Can you perform the following and report back: ...

It is displayed as follows,
(libmesh) pengwei@pengwei-virtual-machine: (next)
~/projects/libmesh/moose/test
$ mamba list 
# packages in environment at /home/pengwei/mambaforge3/envs/libmesh:
#
# Name                    Version                   Build  Channel\

It looks like you started with these instructions: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
and then went with these: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
Is this correct?

Yes, I used https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html first, then created a folder ./projects/libmesh/moose to clone the moose repository, and then based on https:/ /mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html to install.

I think you followed one too many instructions, based on what I am seeing in the libmesh_diagnostic.log. Was there a reason to try and perform the HPC instructions? The Conda instructions are best used for single workstations/laptops (which I think you have).
The HPC instructions are for those wishing to use a high performance job scheduling capable environment. Where typically you need optimized binaries designed to work specifically with that system's MPI infrastructure.
If following the HPC instructions was an accident, I believe the only steps left for you to do is:
mamba activate moose
mamba install moose-libmesh moose-tools
mamba deactivate
mamba activate moose
cd ~/projects/libmesh/moose/test
make clobber all       # to clean up any previous build
make -j 6
./run_tests -j 6

Was there a reason to try and perform the HPC instructions?

My purpose is to be able to link libmesh directly, so that I can have a deeper understanding of moose, considering that I need to create my own model, this is related to mesh data.
I think my libmesh has been installed, but when I execute the following code,
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j4
It shows make: python-config: Command not found, how to solve this?
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/mesh_Unity.C...
Building and linking /home/pengwei/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit/hit.so...
/home/pengwei/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit/hit.cpp:4:10: fatal error: Python.h: No such file or directory
    4 | #include "Python.h"
      |          ^~~~~~~~~~
compilation terminated.
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/pengwei/projects/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/exodiff.C...
make: *** [/home/pengwei/projects/moose/framework/moose.mk:124: /home/pengwei/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit/hit.so] Error 1
make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
Woohoo!! It works using sudo apt-get install python3-dev

🎉  Nice! Looks like you got it sorted!
FYI, you can still use Conda instead of the manual install (if you choose). You simply install only the things that moose-libmesh requires. Which I admit, is not documented. But that package install would look something like:
mamba create -n just-petsc moose-petsc
mamba activate just-petsc
cd moose/scripts
export METHODS=oprof MOOSE_JOBS=6   # build profile method, using 6 cores
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
export METHOD=oprof                 # build moose using same method as libMesh
cd ../test
make -j 6
./run_tests --oprof                 # run tests using the moose_test-oprof binary
There are several 'METHOD(S)' available, FYI; oprof, opt, devel, dbg
The description of what each means can be found here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_development/build_system.html

node.title: Postprocessor Output
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I have a calculation with 10.000 timesteps in the course of 10 seconds. I want to output data with a Postprocessor but only at certain times (0, 0.2, 0.6, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 10 seconds) and not at every timestep because that would result in a huge amount of irrelevant .csv documents. Is there a way to do this in MOOSE?

I found the solution. In the Outputs-Block use
[csv]
  type = CSV
  sync_times = '0.2 0.6 ...'
  sync_only = true
[]
useful!
